facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 301 of 1958 is an appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated February 21, 1958, of the Madhya Pradesh High Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 301 of 1958. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated February 21, 1958, of the Madhya Pradesh High Court at Jabalpur in Letters Patent Appeal No. 22 of 1958, against the order dated February 20, 1958, of the said High Court in Misc. Petition No. 266 of 1957.

facts.text: The second appellant is the Municipal Committee of Dhamtari constituted under the C. P. and Berar Municipalities Act, 1922 (Act 11 of 1922).

anchor.surface_text: 1958. September 30. The following Judgments were delivered DAS C.J.-There are two appellants in this appeal. The second appellant is the Municipal Committee of Dhamtari companystituted under the C. P. and Berar Municipalities Act, 1922  Act 11 of 1922  and the first appellant is its President having been elected as such on July 10, 1956.

facts.text: The first appellant was elected as President of the Municipal Committee on July 10, 1956, and assumed charge on July 27, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: and the first appellant is its President having been elected as such on July 10, 1956. He assumed charge of his office as President on July 27, 1956. It may be mentioned that he was returned as a Congress candidate but has since been expelled from that party for having companytested the last general election as an independent candidate against the Congress candidate.

facts.text: The first appellant was returned as a Congress candidate but has since been expelled from that party for contesting the last general election as an independent candidate.

anchor.surface_text: It may be mentioned that he was returned as a Congress candidate but has since been expelled from that party for having companytested the last general election as an independent candidate against the Congress candidate. It appears that there are two factions in the Municipal Committee.

facts.text: There are two factions in the Municipal Committee.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that there are two factions in the Municipal Committee. The first appellant alleges that one Dhurmal Daga, a member of the companymittee belonging to the Congress party was on August 7, 1956, deflected importing within the municipal limits certain cloth without paying the octroi duty.

facts.text: The first appellant alleges that Dhurmal Daga, a member of the committee belonging to the Congress party, was on August 7, 1956, detected importing cloth without paying octroi duty.

anchor.surface_text: The first appellant alleges that one Dhurmal Daga, a member of the companymittee belonging to the Congress party was on August 7, 1956, deflected importing within the municipal limits certain cloth without paying the octroi duty. Dhurmal Daga, on the other hand, alleged that the first appellant was guilty of grave mismanagement of the affairs of the Municipal Committee and went on hunger strike for securing the appointment of a companymittee to enquire into the misconduct of the first appellant.

facts.text: Dhurmal Daga alleged that the first appellant was guilty of grave mismanagement and went on hunger strike.

anchor.surface_text: Dhurmal Daga, on the other hand, alleged that the first appellant was guilty of grave mismanagement of the affairs of the Municipal Committee and went on hunger strike for securing the appointment of a companymittee to enquire into the misconduct of the first appellant. Copies of the leaflets companytaining the demands and charges which are said to have been widely distributed are annexures I and 11 to the present petition.

facts.text: Several persons and firms preferred charges against the first appellant.

anchor.surface_text: Copies of the leaflets companytaining the demands and charges which are said to have been widely distributed are annexures I and 11 to the present petition. It appears that several persons and firms also preferred charges against the first appellant, the President of the Municipal Committee.

facts.text: The Collector, Raipur, personally intervened and persuaded Dhurmal Daga to abandon the fast on assurance to look into the matter.

anchor.surface_text: The Collector, Raipur, personally intervened and persuaded the said Dhurmal Daga to abandon the fast on an assurance that he would look into the matter. The Collector deputed one Shri N. R. Rana the Additional Deputy Collector to enquire into the companyplaints of maladministration of the affairs of the Municipal Committee.

facts.text: The Collector deputed Shri N. R. Rana, Additional Deputy Collector, to enquire into complaints by Memorandum dated August 24, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: The Collector deputed one Shri N. R. Rana the Additional Deputy Collector to enquire into the companyplaints of maladministration of the affairs of the Municipal Committee. By a Memorandum No. K J N. P. Dhamtari dated August 24, 1956, the said N. R. Rana called upon the first appellant as tile President of the second appellant to give detailed explanation of each companyplaint, a list of which was enclosed therewith.

facts.text: The first appellant submitted detailed explanations to the charges.

anchor.surface_text: By a Memorandum No. K J N. P. Dhamtari dated August 24, 1956, the said N. R. Rana called upon the first appellant as tile President of the second appellant to give detailed explanation of each companyplaint, a list of which was enclosed therewith. A companyy of that memorandum along with its 22 enclosures 1444 is annexed to the petition and marked 111.

facts.text: The Additional Deputy Collector held the enquiry, and the petitioner was present on some occasions.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court states that it had gone through the materials on which the State Government based its action on enquiry into the charges levelled against the Municipal Committee and that the records of the enquiry showed thaton some occasions the petitioner was present duringthe enquiry . Thereis numbersuggestion that the appellants wanted an opportunity to adduce any evidence or were prevented from doing so or that they were in any way hampered in their defence.

facts.text: State Government published notification on November 18, 1957, appointing Shri B. P. Jain as Executive Officer for 18 months under s.53-A.

anchor.surface_text: On November 18, 1957, a numberification was published in the Official Gazette whereby the State Government, in exercise of the powers companyferred on it by s. 53-A of the C. P. Berar Municipalities Act, 1922, appointed one Shri B. P. Jain, the second respondent before us, as the Executive Officer of the Municipal Committee, Dhamtari, for a period of 18 months with certain powers as therein mentioned.

facts.text: The notification lists grounds a to o for the Municipal Committee's incompetency.

anchor.surface_text: Dated, Bhopal, the 18th November, 1957, No. 9262/11538-U- XVIII-Whereas it appears to the State Government that the Municipal Committee, Dhamtari, has proved itself incompetent to perform the duties imposed on it by or under the Central Provinces and Berar Municipalities Act, 1922  11 of 1922 , inasmuch as it-  a granted grain and building advances to the employees without prior sanction and numberefforts were made for their recovery,  b  showed carelessness in cases of embezzlement 1445 of the employees and did number report such cases to Government, ...

facts.text: Appellants filed writ petition on December 21, 1957, obtained stay on January 11, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: On December 21, 1957, the two appellants before us presented before the Madhya Pradesh High Court the writ petition out of which the present appeal has arisen and on January 11, 1958, obtained an order staying the operation of the order of appointment of the Executive Officer.

facts.text: High Court dismissed writ petition on February 20, 1958; Letters Patent Appeal dismissed February 21, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: The writ petition was dismissed on February 20, 1958. There was a Letters Patent Appeal which was dismissed in limine on February 21, 1958.

facts.text: Supreme Court granted special leave on April 1, 1958; vacated stay on May 13, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: The application for -certificate under Arts. 132 and 133 was refused on March 21, 1958. The present appellants applied for and on April 1, 1958, obtained from this Court special leave to appeal from the judgment of the Madhya Pradesh High Court. The interim stay order made by this Court was eventually vacated on May 13, 1958.

facts.text: Mr. Rana submitted report on November 22, 1956, forwarded to State Government on April 24, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: In pursuance of that assurance Mr. Rana, Deputy Collector held an enquiry and called the explanation of tile Municipal Committee and its President and submitted his report on November 22, 1956, which was forwarded to the State Government on April 24, 1957.

facts.text: No suggestion that appellants were prevented from adducing evidence or hampered in defence.

anchor.surface_text: Thereis numbersuggestion that the appellants wanted an opportunity to adduce any evidence or were prevented from doing so or that they were in any way hampered in their defence. Presumably the Additional Deputy Collector had made a report which in due companyrse must have been forwarded to the State Government.

facts.text: The court finds the action under s.53-A was administrative, not quasi-judicial, and principles of natural justice complied with via the enquiry.

anchor.surface_text: In my judgment, the action taken by the State Government under s. 53-A is number a judicial or quasi-judicial act but is an administrative act.

facts.text: Charge of mala fides not pressed before Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: There was a charge of mala fide made against the State Government founded on the fact that the first appellants leaving the Congress party had resulted in ill-will towards the first appellant of that -party which was the ruling party in the State Government, but as that charge has number been pressed before us numberhing further need be said about it.

facts.text: High Court went through materials and records of enquiry.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court states that it had gone through the materials on which the State Government based its action on enquiry into the charges levelled against the Municipal Committee and that the records of the enquiry showed thaton some occasions the petitioner was present duringthe enquiry .

Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated February 21, 1958, of the Madhya Pradesh High Court at Jabalpur in Letters Patent Appeal No. 22 of 1958, against the order dated February 20, 1958, of the said High Court in Misc. Petition No. 266 of 1957.

On December 21, 1957, the two appellants before us presented before the Madhya Pradesh High Court the writ petition out of which the present appeal has arisen and on January 11, 1958, obtained an order staying the operation of the order of appointment of the Executive Officer.

issues.text: Whether the impugned notification, though purporting to be under s. 53-A of the C.P. Berar Municipalities Act, 1922, was in substance and reality made under s. 57 thereof?

anchor.surface_text: that though the Notification purports to have been made in exercise of the power,, conferred on the State Government by s. 53-A, in substance and in reality it has been made under s. 57 of the Act

issues.text: Whether, if the notification is held to be under s. 57, it is ultra vires and invalid for failure to comply with the requirement under s. 57(5) of affording reasonable opportunity to the committee to furnish an explanation?

anchor.surface_text: that if the Notification is held to be one made under s. 57 it is ultra vires and bad since the statutory requirements of affording reasonable opportunity to explain has not been complied with

issues.text: Whether the impugned notification under s. 53-A is ultra vires for breach of rules of natural justice by not giving opportunity to the appellants to defend themselves?

anchor.surface_text: that even if the impugned Notification be held to come within s. 53-A it is still ultra vires since before promulgating it the State Government has committed a breach of the rules of natural justice in not giving any opportunity to the appellants to defend themselves.

issues.text: Whether the State Government's action under s. 53-A constitutes a quasi-judicial function such that a writ of certiorari lies to quash the notification?

anchor.surface_text: The law is well- settled that a writ of certiorari will lie to control such a statutory body if it purports to act without jurisdiction or in excess of it or in violation of the principles of natural justice... provided that... it can be said to be a quasi- judicial body entrusted with quasi-judicial functions.

issues.text: Whether s. 53-A imposes a duty on the State Government to act judicially in determining the committee's incompetency and appointing an Executive Officer?

anchor.surface_text: It is, therefore, necessary to ascertain the true nature of the functions entrusted to and exercised by the State Government under s. 53-A of the Act... the real and determining test... is whether the statute has expressly or impliedly imposed upon the statutory body the duty to act judicially

arguments.claim: s.53-A administrative, not quasi-judicial; no duty to act judicially per Atkin LJ test; no lis; no procedure prescribed unlike s.57

anchor.surface_text: The law is well- settled that a writ of certiorari will lie to control such a statutory body if it purports to act without jurisdiction or in excess of it or in violation of the principles of natural justice, or commits any error apparent on the face of the records, provided that... quasi-judicial body

arguments.claim: Govt has option under overlapping conditions; s.53-A temporary less drastic vs s.57 dissolution; can treat abuses as incompetency

anchor.surface_text: Re. i and ii These two points are interrelated... the sections under consideration only confer certain powers on the State Government but that the latter is not bound to take any action under either of them... differ materially in their scope and effect.

arguments.claim: Prior enquiry by Additional Deputy Collector; explanations submitted; president present; no prevention of evidence; fair play observed

anchor.surface_text: I have already recounted the events... the appellants have had more than fair play. It is said that the State Government did not hold any enquiry... All the charges levelled against the appellants were forwarded to them, and they submitted explanation.

arguments.claim: Incompetency is jurisdictional fact but determination administrative; no implication of judicial duty from statute

anchor.surface_text: The first requisite, however, is an objective fact, namely, whether the committee is or is not competent... does not require that that fact must be determined judicially. The sole question is, does the statute require the State Government to act judicially.

arguments.claim: s.25-A analogous; no judicial enquiry required

anchor.surface_text: Section 25-A which deals with the appointment of a Chief Executive Officer... Nobody will say that the State Government must exercise the powers under s. 25-A after holding any judicial enquiry.

arguments.claim: Even if quasi-judicial, natural justice complied via enquiry

anchor.surface_text: In my opinion, the determination... is immaterial... inasmuch as an inquiry had been instituted... full opportunity had been given... principles of natural justice had been complied with

arguments.claim: Function under s.53-A administrative; tests like no lis inter partes, policy/expediency

anchor.surface_text: I am of the view that the action taken by the State Government under s. 53-A of the Act is in its true nature an administrative act... tests have been laid down for example- whether there is a lis inter partes

holdings.text: The impugned notification was made validly under section 53-A of the C.P. and Berar Municipalities Act, 1922, and not under section 57 thereof.

anchor.surface_text: In my judgment the State Government was well within its rights, in exercise of its option, to take action, under s. 53-A as it has in terms purported to do. To say that because some of the findings amount to abuse of power the State Government must act under s. 57 is to deprive it of its discretion which the Act undoubtedly confers on it.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Sections 53-A and 57 overlap on incompetency but differ in scope, duration, and consequences; government has discretion to choose less drastic temporary measure under 53-A even if abuses present, as they evidence incompetency; express terms and effect confirm 53-A.

holdings.text: Argument that notification under section 57 is ultra vires for non-compliance with section 57(5) does not arise.

anchor.surface_text: In this view of the matter the argument of invalidity of the action founded on non-compliance with the requirements of sub-s. (5) of s. 57 does not arise for consideration at all.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Since notification held under 53-A, not 57, procedural requirement of 57(5) inapplicable.

holdings.text: Action under section 53-A is an administrative act, not judicial or quasi-judicial; no duty to act judicially imposed by statute.

anchor.surface_text: In my judgment, the action taken by the State Government under s. 53-A is not a judicial or quasi-judicial act but is an administrative act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies Atkin LJ test (legal authority, affects rights, duty to act judicially); no lis inter partes, no prescribed procedure like s.57(5), temporary nature, analogy to s.25-A, precedents (Kusaldas Advani, Electricity Commissioners); statute lacks express/implied duty.

holdings.text: No writ of certiorari lies against the State Government's action under section 53-A as it is purely administrative.

anchor.surface_text: It is equally well-settled that certiorari will not lie to correct the errors of a statutory body which is entrusted with purely administrative functions.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Certiorari only for quasi-judicial bodies acting without/in excess of jurisdiction, natural justice breach, or record error; s.53-A administrative per statutory construction and precedents.

holdings.text: No breach of principles of natural justice in the action under section 53-A; appellants had more than fair play through prior enquiry.

anchor.surface_text: If the action taken under that section is to be regarded as an administrative action, as I hold it should be, then I have no doubt that the appellants have had more than fair play.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Administrative action requires fair play, not full judicial hearing; prior Deputy Collector enquiry, notice of charges, explanations submitted, personal attendance, no denial of evidence opportunity; sufficient even if quasi-judicial.

holdings.text: Charge of mala fides against State Government not pressed and rejected.

anchor.surface_text: There was a charge of mala fide made against the State Government... but as that charge has not been pressed before us nothing further need be said about it.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Petitioner abandoned argument before Supreme Court.

holdings.text: Invocation of Article 226 not available to challenge the administrative action under section 53-A.

anchor.surface_text: Art. 226 of the Constitution is not open to the present petitioner.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Affirms High Court; no jurisdiction for writ against administrative act.

precedents.citation: Province of Bombay v. Kusaldas S. Advani

anchor.surface_text: In Province of Bombay v. Kusaldas S. Advani this Court has discussed at considerable length the nature of the two kinds of act, judicial and administrative, and has laid down certain tests for ascertaining whether the act of a statutory body is a quasijudicial act or an administrative act. It will, therefore, 1 1950 S.C.R, 621.

precedents.case_name: Province of Bombay v Kusaldas S Advani
precedents.cited_proposition: nature of the two kinds of act, judicial and administrative, and tests for ascertaining whether the act of a statutory body is a quasi-judicial act or an administrative act

anchor.surface_text: the celebrated definition of a quasi- judicial body given by Atkin L. J. as he then was, in Rex v. Electricity Commissioners and which still holds the field. It runs as follows Whenever any body of persons having legal authority to determine questions affecting rights of subjects, and having the duty to act judicially act in excess of their legal authority they are subject to the controlling jurisdiction of the Kings Bench

precedents.cited_proposition: definition of a quasi-judicial body: body of persons having legal authority to determine questions affecting rights of subjects, and having the duty to act judicially
precedents.cited_holding: Whenever any body of persons having legal authority to determine questions affecting rights of subjects, and having the duty to act judicially act in excess of their legal authority they are subject to the controlling jurisdiction of the Kings Bench

anchor.surface_text: This definition was accepted as correct in Rex v. London Count? Council 2 and many subsequent cases both in England and in this country.

precedents.cited_proposition: accepted the definition of quasi-judicial body from Rex v Electricity Commissioners

precedents.citation: R. v. Manchester Legal Aid Committee

anchor.surface_text: Relying on paragraphs 114 and 115 of Halsburys Laws of England, 3rd Edition, Volume 11, at pages 5558 and citing the case of R. v. Manchester Legal Aid Committee 1 , learned counsel for the appellants contends that where a statute requires a decision to be arrived at purely from the point of view of policy or expediency the authority is under no duty to act judicially.

precedents.case_name: R v Manchester Legal Aid Committee
precedents.cited_proposition: where a statute requires a decision to be arrived at purely from the point of view of policy or expediency the authority is under no duty to act judicially

precedents.citation: Province of Bombay v. K. S. Advani

anchor.surface_text: The principles deducible from the various judicial decisions considered by this Court in the Province of Bombay v. K. S. Advani 1 at page 725 were thus formulated, namely that if a statute empowers an authority, not being a Court in the ordinary sense, to decide disputes arising out of a claim made by one party under the statute which claim is opposed by another party and to determine the respective rights of the contesting parties who are opposed to each other, there is a lis and prima facie and in the absence of anything in the statute to the contrary it is the duty of the authority to act judicially and the decision of the authority is a quasi-judicial act

precedents.case_name: Province of Bombay v K S Advani
precedents.cited_proposition: principles on when an authority has duty to act judicially: lis inter partes or authority affecting subject must act judicially

anchor.surface_text: Section 53-A, it is pointed out, differs materially in this respect from s. 3 of the Bombay Land Requisition Ordinance V of 1947 which was considered by this Court in Kusaldas Advanis case 1 .

precedents.cited_proposition: interpretation of 'in the opinion of the Provincial Government' as subjective determination making action administrative

anchor.surface_text: In Advanis case 1 Kania C.J. with whom Patanjali Sastri J. agreed, said at page 632 The respondents argument that whenever there is a determination of a fact which affects the rights of parties, the decision is quasi-judicial, does not appear to be sound.

precedents.cited_proposition: not every determination of fact affecting rights is quasi-judicial
precedents.cited_holding: The respondents argument that whenever there is a determination of a fact which affects the rights of parties, the decision is quasi-judicial, does not appear to be sound.

precedents.citation: B. v. Legislative Committee of the Church Assembly

anchor.surface_text: I found support for my opinion on the following passage occurring in the judgment of Lord Hewart C. J. in B. v. Legislative Committee of the Church Assembly 1 In order that a body may satisfy the required test it is not enough that it should have legal authority to determine questions affecting the rights of subjects there must be super-added to that characteristic the further characteristic that the body has the duty to act judicially.

precedents.case_name: B v Legislative Committee of the Church Assembly
precedents.cited_proposition: for quasi-judicial, must have duty to act judicially in addition to legal authority to determine rights
precedents.cited_holding: In order that a body may satisfy the required test it is not enough that it should have legal authority to determine questions affecting the rights of subjects there must be super-added to that characteristic the further characteristic that the body has the duty to act judicially.

anchor.surface_text: The above passage was quoted with approval by Lord Radcliffe in delivering the judgment of the Privy Council in Nakkuda Alis case

precedents.cited_proposition: quoted with approval the passage on duty to act judicially

anchor.surface_text: Learned counsel for the appellants relied on the case of Capel v. Child 1 . That decision clearly went upon the construction of the statute that came up for consideration.

precedents.cited_proposition: duty to act judicially inferred from statute allowing action on affidavits

precedents.citation: Cooper v. The Wandsworth Board of Works

anchor.surface_text: appearing in the judgment of Byles J. in Cooper v. The Wandsworth Board of Works 1 is apposite. The decision in the last mentioned case clearly establishes that in some cases it may be necessary to give an opportunity to a party to have his say before an administrative action is taken against him.

precedents.case_name: Cooper v Wandsworth Board of Works
precedents.cited_proposition: rules of natural justice or fair play require opportunity to be heard even in administrative actions

precedents.citation: R. v. Manchester Legal Aid Committee

anchor.surface_text: The last two tests were discussed and considered in R. v. Manchester Legal Aid Committee 1 .

precedents.case_name: R v Manchester Legal Aid Committee
precedents.cited_proposition: tests for duty to act judicially based on policy/expediency vs evidence/lis

precedents.citation: Westminster Corporation v. London and North Western Railway Co.

anchor.surface_text: per Lord Halsbury L. C. in the Westminster Corporation v. London and North Western Railway Co. 1 . And it cannot on that ground a

precedents.case_name: Westminster Corporation v London and North Western Railway Co
precedents.cited_proposition: court cannot question discretion of authority choosing which statutory power to exercise unless abuse

anchor.surface_text: In my judgment the State Government was well within its rights, in exercise of its option, to take action, under s. 53-A as it has in terms purported to do. To say that because some of the findings amount to abuse of power the State Government must act under s. 57 is to deprive it of its discretion which the Act undoubtedly confers on it.

In my judgment there has been numberremissness on the part of the State Government. For reasons stated above I would dismiss this appeal. BHAGWATI J.-.I also agree that the appeal should be dismissed with companyts but would like to add a few words of my own. I have had the benefit of reading the judgments prepared by my Lord the Chief Justice, Kapur J. and Subba Rao J.
In this view of the matter the argument of invalidity of the action founded on non-compliance with the requirements of sub-s. (5) of s. 57 does not arise for consideration at all.

In my judgment there has been numberremissness on the part of the State Government. For reasons stated above I would dismiss this appeal.
